path_metadata.path_title: Recruitment Intern to HR Manager Readiness Path

simulation_metadata.why_this_matters_for_getting_hired: Hiring managers judge whether you can produce a clean shortlist fast without missing risk.

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: The hiring manager pings: “I need 5 solid candidates for today’s panel—now.”
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: ATS shortlist view (limited fields; no deep profiles)
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Hiring manager questions your judgment in front of the panel coordinator

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: A senior interviewer flags one candidate as “too good to be true” minutes before scheduling.
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: You must decide whether to remove a top candidate and risk missing the hire

workplace_context.business_state: Hiring quality audit after mis-hire last quarter

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Your shortlist is questioned: “Why are these profiles even here?”
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Shortlist rationale email (tight format; 5 bullets max)
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Trust moment: keep autonomy or get micromanaged

step_level_design.instruction_question: Pick 5 candidates to send to the hiring manager right now.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This tests whether you can produce a usable shortlist when the business is moving faster than perfect information. HR Managers earn trust by selecting candidates who are interview-ready today, not “maybe with training.” Aim for candidates who match the non-negotiables and reduce the risk of wasting panel time. Your goal is a shortlist that survives scrutiny even if a detail later changes.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You see 12 candidate tiles with only role-critical signals (current role, key skills, tenure, notice period, compensation range). Tap to select 5; a ‘shortlist health’ meter updates based on role-fit and risk balance.
options_inputs: Select candidates with direct role match and stable tenure
Select candidates with strong brands but partial skill match
Select candidates with fastest joining only
Select candidates with the highest years of experience regardless of relevance

outcomes.correct: Shortlist is role-fit heavy with manageable risk notes
outcomes.partially_correct: Shortlist has 1–2 questionable profiles but is defensible
outcomes.incorrect: Shortlist is driven by weak proxies (brand/years) and wastes panel time

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: The panel trusts your shortlist enough to proceed—or starts re-checking everything you send.

step_level_design.instruction_question: One candidate looks great—but one detail doesn’t add up. Keep or drop?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: High-paying teams expect HR Managers to spot ‘too good to be true’ signals without overreacting. This step evaluates whether you can protect hiring quality while keeping hiring speed. You’re not expected to be omniscient—only to make a decision that reduces downstream risk and is explainable to leadership.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You tap the candidate tile to open a one-screen ‘risk snapshot’ (inconsistent dates, unusually rapid promotions, vague project claims). Choose an action; the system reveals what happens in scheduling and interview outcome.
options_inputs: Keep on shortlist; add a specific verification note for interviewers
Drop immediately to avoid any risk
Keep and ignore the detail; move fast
Pause the entire shortlist until full verification is done

outcomes.correct: You contain risk without killing speed
outcomes.partially_correct: You reduce risk but slow the pipeline more than needed
outcomes.incorrect: You either ignore risk or freeze hiring unnecessarily

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your decision either prevents a later embarrassment—or creates a preventable interview failure.

step_level_design.instruction_question: The hiring manager asks: “Why these 5?” Reply in 5 bullets.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers are judged on clarity under pressure. This step checks if you can justify a shortlist in business language that a hiring manager actually trusts. Your explanation should show a consistent selection logic and surface any known risks upfront so the manager isn’t surprised later.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose 5 bullet-lines from a pool to form your rationale email. Each choice shifts the manager’s trust meter (clarity, ownership, risk transparency).
options_inputs: Lead with must-have match, then role outcomes, then risk notes
Lead with brand names, then years, then vague ‘culture fit’
Lead with constraints and excuses, then selections
Lead with risk notes only, then no positives

outcomes.correct: Rationale is crisp, consistent, and risk-aware
outcomes.partially_correct: Rationale is okay but misses one key business angle
outcomes.incorrect: Rationale is defensive, vague, or proxy-driven

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Leadership either increases your autonomy—or treats you as a coordinator only.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Two interview slots open up. Swap in a borderline candidate or keep your top 5 intact?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This tests whether you protect shortlist integrity when logistics create temptation to ‘fill slots.’ HR Managers are accountable for pipeline quality, not just scheduling. Your decision should reflect a clear standard: either uphold quality or knowingly trade it off and document why.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: A scheduling screen shows two panels available and your shortlist status. You pick an action and see immediate downstream effects (panel satisfaction, candidate experience, rework).
options_inputs: Keep top 5 intact; use waitlist and ask for a reschedule
Swap in the borderline candidate to keep panels busy
Cancel the interviews until you source fresh candidates
Ask the hiring manager to decide without your recommendation

outcomes.correct: You protect quality while managing expectations
outcomes.partially_correct: You keep momentum but increase rework risk
outcomes.incorrect: You break standards or offload accountability

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You either prevent ‘pipeline pollution’ or create it.

simulations.end_state: This is exactly the kind of situation HR Managers are judged on.

simulation_metadata.why_this_matters_for_getting_hired: You’re judged on how you contain interview breakdowns without damaging trust or candidate experience.

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Candidate waits 18 minutes; interviewer doesn’t join. Candidate threatens to withdraw.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Live interview schedule + escalation chat thread
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Candidate posts about the experience and tags the company

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Candidate reports inappropriate comments during the interview.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Candidate complaint note (confidential) + internal escalation channel
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Leadership asks: “Is this a compliance risk?”

workplace_context.business_state: Tight timelines; zero tolerance for reputational risk

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: You must decide whether to re-interview, change panel, or end the process.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Decision summary to hiring manager (short, defensible)
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Your judgment is compared to “HR Manager standard”

step_level_design.instruction_question: The candidate is waiting. What do you do in the next 2 minutes?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: In real hiring, speed and tone protect the employer brand. This evaluates whether you respond like an owner: contain the candidate’s frustration, establish a next step, and keep options open without overpromising. Business value is preventing drop-offs and reputation damage while keeping the panel accountable.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose a single message to send to the candidate. The candidate’s ‘trust level’ shifts immediately based on your tone and specificity.
options_inputs: Apologise, give a precise next update time, and offer a fast reschedule option
Ask them to wait; say the interviewer is busy
Say nothing until you confirm internally
Offer compensation immediately to calm them

outcomes.correct: Candidate stays engaged; brand impact contained
outcomes.partially_correct: Candidate stays but confidence drops
outcomes.incorrect: Candidate withdraws or escalates publicly

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You either stabilise the situation—or turn a delay into a reputational incident.

step_level_design.instruction_question: The interviewer still hasn’t joined. Escalate, replace, or reschedule?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers protect process integrity: they don’t let candidates hang, and they don’t let interviewers treat hiring casually. This tests whether you take decisive action that keeps quality and fairness intact. Business value is preventing waste while signaling high standards internally.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: A schedule view shows alternate interviewers and slots. You pick an action and immediately see downstream effects (panel alignment, candidate sentiment, timeline).
options_inputs: Replace with a trained backup interviewer and proceed
Reschedule to the next available slot and document the no-show
Wait longer to avoid disrupting the panel
Cancel the process and close the candidate

outcomes.correct: You preserve fairness and momentum with accountability
outcomes.partially_correct: You preserve fairness but lose speed
outcomes.incorrect: You prioritise convenience over candidate experience

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your action defines whether hiring runs like a disciplined system or chaos.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Candidate reports an inappropriate comment. What’s your next move?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This evaluates HR maturity. HR Managers don’t dismiss sensitive signals or turn them into gossip—they capture facts, protect confidentiality, and escalate appropriately. Business value is reducing compliance risk and protecting employer brand while treating the candidate fairly.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose a structured response path (fact capture → escalation → panel adjustment). The system reveals how leadership views your handling.
options_inputs: Capture details neutrally, reassure confidentiality, escalate to HRBP/People Ops lead
Tell the candidate you’ll ‘talk to the interviewer’ and get back later
Ignore unless the candidate repeats the complaint
Ask the interviewer directly first to ‘confirm’

outcomes.correct: Risk contained and handled defensibly
outcomes.partially_correct: Handled with delays or minor process gaps
outcomes.incorrect: Creates exposure and trust loss

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Leadership either trusts your discretion—or worries you’ll mishandle sensitive issues.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Decide: re-interview, change panel, or end the candidacy.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers are accountable for outcomes, not intentions. This step tests if you can make a fair, business-sound decision that protects quality and avoids repeat incidents. Your decision must be explainable to leadership and respectful to the candidate.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You pick one path; the simulation shows interview outcome probabilities and brand risk consequences.
options_inputs: Re-interview with a new panel and send a clear reset message
Proceed with current feedback; ignore the incident
End candidacy to avoid any complexity
Delay decision until you gather ‘more signals’

outcomes.correct: Fair reset with leadership-aligned reasoning
outcomes.partially_correct: Defensible but suboptimal business outcome
outcomes.incorrect: Unfair, risky, or evasive decision

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your judgment either prevents repeat incidents—or normalises them.

simulations.end_state: This is exactly the kind of situation HR Managers are judged on.

simulation_metadata.why_this_matters_for_getting_hired: You’re evaluated on whether you add judgment to decisions, not just pass messages.

recruiter_readable_proof: Risk Mitigation Plan for the Chosen Candidate

workplace_context.business_state: Role is tied to a client delivery deadline

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Hiring manager says: “Pick. We need the offer out in 1 hour.”
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Your recommendation is treated as your judgment, not ‘admin input’

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Panel feedback is split; one senior interviewer objects strongly.
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Senior interviewer challenges your recommendation live

workplace_context.business_state: Comp constraints; candidate market is hot

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Comp band may not match the top candidate’s expectations.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Offer risk note (1 screen) to leadership
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: You’re judged on whether you saw the offer failure coming

step_level_design.instruction_question: Choose who you recommend for offer: Candidate A or B.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers are expected to make a call with imperfect information. This tests whether you can identify the trade-off that matters for business outcomes—delivery risk, ramp time, team impact—rather than personal preference. Your recommendation should be explainable and tied to what the role must achieve in the next 90 days.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You see two candidate cards with only decision-grade signals. Tap one to recommend; the system reveals immediate leadership reaction.
options_inputs: Recommend Candidate A (faster ramp, weaker long-term upside)
Recommend Candidate B (strong upside, higher ramp risk)
Recommend ‘no hire’ and restart pipeline
Tell the hiring manager to decide without your view

outcomes.correct: Recommendation matches role urgency and is defensible
outcomes.partially_correct: Recommendation is arguable but misses a key risk
outcomes.incorrect: Avoids accountability or ignores role constraints

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your recommendation either accelerates delivery—or seeds a mis-hire risk.

step_level_design.instruction_question: A senior interviewer strongly disagrees. How do you respond in the moment?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This tests whether you can hold a professional line under pressure. HR Managers don’t ‘win arguments’—they clarify decision criteria, surface risk, and steer to a resolution. Business value is preventing indecision paralysis and avoiding political fallout.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You select a response line in a live meeting chat. The disagreement either escalates or resolves based on your choice.
options_inputs: Ask for the specific failure risk and tie it back to role outcomes
Dismiss the concern as ‘subjective’
Switch recommendation immediately to reduce conflict
End the discussion and postpone the decision

outcomes.correct: You de-escalate and improve decision quality
outcomes.partially_correct: You keep calm but don’t resolve the core issue
outcomes.incorrect: You inflame politics or become evasive

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Leadership sees you as a decision partner—or a push-over.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Document the recommendation in 3 lines for leadership approval.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This evaluates whether you can translate judgment into a crisp, reviewable justification. HR Managers are trusted when they can state: why this candidate, what risk exists, and how it will be managed. Business value is faster approvals and fewer reversals.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose 3 lines from a pool to form a leadership-ready note; each line changes approval likelihood.
options_inputs: Tie to role outcomes and timeline
Surface the key risk transparently
Propose a mitigation step (e.g., reference check focus area)
Add general praise without evidence

outcomes.correct: Approval likely with clear risk management
outcomes.partially_correct: Approval possible but questions remain
outcomes.incorrect: Vague note triggers delays and rework

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your clarity either speeds the offer—or stalls the process.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Comp band might not match. What do you do before sending the offer?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers prevent avoidable offer failures. This step tests whether you anticipate candidate behavior and align internal stakeholders early. Business value is reducing offer drop-offs that waste weeks of pipeline time.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You pick an action; the simulation reveals candidate response and internal alignment outcomes.
options_inputs: Run a quick expectation check with the candidate and align internally on flex points
Send the offer and negotiate only if they push back
Delay the offer until next quarter budget clears
Ask the hiring manager to handle comp discussions alone

outcomes.correct: Offer risk reduced with minimal delay
outcomes.partially_correct: Offer risk reduced but timeline takes a hit
outcomes.incorrect: High likelihood of offer rejection or internal conflict

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You either secure the hire—or create a predictable rejection.

simulations.end_state: This is exactly the kind of situation HR Managers are judged on.

simulation_metadata.why_this_matters_for_getting_hired: You’re judged on whether you protect employer brand and close risk when offers go sideways.

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Candidate rejects and threatens to post a screenshot of the offer email.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Offer email thread (only; no long docs)
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Leadership asks: “Are we about to look bad publicly?”

workplace_context.business_state: Hot market; competitor offers within 24 hours

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Candidate gives a 12-hour ultimatum with a counter.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: One-screen comp flex summary (band + approval limits)
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Hiring manager pushes you to “just match it”

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Candidate claims the offer is unfair vs peers.
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Short fairness justification note to leadership
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Compliance tone: “Can we defend this if questioned?”

step_level_design.instruction_question: Candidate threatens to post the offer screenshot. What do you say first?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This tests brand protection under stress. HR Managers respond quickly, respectfully, and with control—without escalating conflict or making promises they can’t keep. Business value is preventing reputational damage while preserving a chance to resolve the issue privately.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You select a first-response message. The simulation shows whether the candidate calms down, escalates, or disengages.
options_inputs: Acknowledge, invite a private call immediately, and commit to a clear next step
Warn them not to post or mention legal consequences
Ignore and wait for the hiring manager’s guidance
Offer a raise immediately to stop the post

outcomes.correct: Escalation contained; relationship salvage possible
outcomes.partially_correct: Contained but candidate remains distrustful
outcomes.incorrect: Candidate escalates; leadership confidence drops

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your response either prevents a brand incident—or triggers one.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Candidate gives a 12-hour counteroffer ultimatum. What’s your move?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers are judged on controlled negotiation, not panic. This step evaluates whether you can align stakeholders fast and respond within constraints. Business value is reducing offer drop-offs while avoiding inconsistent or unfair comp decisions.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose an action path; the simulation reveals approval speed, candidate response, and internal fallout risk.”
options_inputs: Clarify candidate priorities, check internal flex, and respond with a structured counter
Match immediately to close fast
Reject the counter outright to protect policy
Delay response and hope they wait

outcomes.correct: Fast, controlled negotiation within rules
outcomes.partially_correct: Outcome okay but creates internal risk or delay
outcomes.incorrect: Offer collapses or triggers policy inconsistency

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You either close a hire cleanly—or create a precedent that haunts future offers.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Hiring manager pressures: “Just match it.” What do you do?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This tests whether you can hold policy boundaries without becoming obstructive. HR Managers protect the company by being clear on limits while offering alternatives. Business value is preventing runaway comp and preserving trust across teams.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose a response in a tense chat. Leadership confidence shifts based on whether you’re firm + solution-oriented.
options_inputs: State the constraint clearly and propose 2 feasible alternatives
Agree immediately to avoid conflict
Refuse without alternatives
Escalate and exit the discussion

outcomes.correct: You hold boundaries and keep momentum
outcomes.partially_correct: You hold boundaries but slow the process
outcomes.incorrect: You either cave or block progress

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You’re seen as a business partner—or a bottleneck.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Candidate claims unfairness vs peers. Decide what you document for leadership.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: At HR Manager level, you must anticipate defensibility. This evaluates whether you can document a fairness-aware rationale that can withstand scrutiny without oversharing confidential info. Business value is reducing compliance risk and preventing repeat escalations.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You pick 3 points to include in a leadership note; the system reveals whether it’s defensible and whether it triggers rework.
options_inputs: Role scope + level alignment to band
Market benchmark reference (high level)
Approval boundary and exceptions policy
Other employee compensation specifics

outcomes.correct: Defensible note without confidentiality breach
outcomes.partially_correct: Defensible but incomplete; prompts questions
outcomes.incorrect: Creates legal/compliance exposure

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You either protect the company—or create a liability trail.

simulations.end_state: This is exactly the kind of situation HR Managers are judged on.

simulation_metadata.why_this_matters_for_getting_hired: Leaders hire HR Managers who can diagnose hiring failures and improve outcomes fast.
primary_role_competencies_evaluated: Balancing speed, quality, and candidate experience
Executive communication of a fix plan

workplace_context.business_state: Hiring miss; teams understaffed; revenue impact

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: In a leadership review, the CEO says: “Hiring is broken. Fix it.”
scenario_breakdown.central_artefact: Hiring funnel snapshot (one screen; high-level metrics)
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: You’re asked to explain failure in 60 seconds

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Managers blame recruiters; recruiters blame interviewers; candidates are dropping.
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: You must choose which team to confront first

scenario_breakdown.crisis_or_decision_trigger: Leadership demands a 90-day plan with measurable targets.
scenario_breakdown.emotional_peak: Accountability: “If this fails, we change ownership.”

step_level_design.instruction_question: In the review, pick your 60-second explanation: what’s actually failing?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This tests executive judgment. HR Managers must explain failure in a way that leads to action, not blame. You’re expected to identify the most likely constraint from limited data and propose a next step that reduces time-to-hire without sacrificing quality. Business value is restoring hiring confidence and protecting delivery timelines.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You choose one narrative diagnosis line; leadership reaction changes (support vs skepticism).
options_inputs: Interview loop delay is causing drop-offs and offer losses
Sourcing quality is poor; pipeline isn’t role-fit
Recruiters are underperforming; replace the team
Comp bands are uncompetitive; nothing else matters

outcomes.correct: Your diagnosis is plausible and action-oriented
outcomes.partially_correct: Plausible but incomplete; leadership wants proof
outcomes.incorrect: Blame-heavy or unfalsifiable explanation

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Leadership either gives you the mandate—or starts doubting your readiness.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Choose the first lever to pull this week to reduce drop-offs.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers win by picking high-leverage moves. This tests whether you can choose an intervention that changes outcomes quickly while staying realistic in constraints. Business value is immediate improvement without chaos or fairness issues.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You select one lever; the simulation shows effects on speed, quality, and candidate sentiment.
options_inputs: Introduce backup interviewers + strict slot ownership
Add more interview rounds to increase quality
Pause hiring until process is redesigned
Push recruiters to ‘source harder’ without process changes

outcomes.correct: Measurable improvement with controlled risk
outcomes.partially_correct: Improvement but creates new risk or burden
outcomes.incorrect: Worsens outcomes or stalls hiring

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: You either reduce leakage—or create new bottlenecks.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Three candidate journeys show different failures. Which is the real pattern?
step_level_design.explain_this_question: This evaluates your ability to separate anecdote from signal. HR Managers identify repeated failure modes across cases and target them, rather than reacting to the loudest complaint. Business value is fixing the system once, not firefighting forever.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You review 3 short timelines (application → interviews → offer). Tap the pattern you believe is systemic; the simulation reveals whether your hypothesis matches downstream data.
options_inputs: Drop-offs spike after long scheduling gaps
Drop-offs spike after comp discussion
Drop-offs spike after technical round difficulty
No pattern—each case is unique

outcomes.correct: You identify a system-level failure mode
outcomes.partially_correct: You identify a partial pattern
outcomes.incorrect: You miss the pattern and propose scattered fixes

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Your call either focuses the fix—or spreads effort thin.

step_level_design.instruction_question: Draft a 90-day fix plan headline: 3 actions, 2 metrics.
step_level_design.explain_this_question: HR Managers are judged on measurable execution. This tests whether you can propose a plan that leadership can approve quickly and track weekly. Business value is predictable improvement with clear accountability.
step_level_design.artefact_interaction_description: You select 3 actions and 2 success metrics from a pool. The system checks whether they are coherent and measurable.
options_inputs: Actions: reduce scheduling gaps, standardize panels, pre-align comp ranges
Metrics: time-to-interview, offer acceptance rate
Actions: add rounds, add approvals, add forms
Metrics: number of interviews conducted, number of emails sent

outcomes.correct: Plan is coherent with outcome metrics
outcomes.partially_correct: Plan is okay but metrics are weak or lagging
outcomes.incorrect: Plan is activity-based, not outcome-based

step_level_design.immediate_feedback: Impact: Leadership either signs off—or sends you back to rework.

simulations.end_state: This is exactly the kind of situation HR Managers are judged on.
